title: Girl Refuses Offensive Math Problem:Class 4 Girl Refuses To Solve 'Offensive' Math Problem, Writes A Note To Teacher Explaining Why
text:
A girl of class four is earning praises online after she spotted an ‘offensive’ Math problem and refused to solve it. Rhythm Pacheco, a student from Utah, wrote a note to her teacher, after she noticed a Math problem and took a stand against it.

Rhythm’s mother noticed the handwritten note when she was checking her daughter’s homework. She took a picture of the note and posted it on her social media after which thousands of people praised the little girl.

The question which she refused to do was to draw a comparison of weights between three Class 4 students - Isabel, Irene and Sue. It asks how much heavier is Isabel than the lightest student. ‘The table to the right shows the weight of three Grade 4 students. How much heavier is Isabel than the lightest student,’ read the question.

Rhythm got offended by the question and decided not to attempt the question writing ‘What!!! This is offensive. Sorry I won’t right, this its rood (sic)’ . After which she left a note for her teacher writing, ‘Dear Mrs. Shaw, I don’t want to be rude, but I don’t think that math problem was very nice because that’s judging people’s weight. Also, the reason I did not do the sentence is cause I just don’t think that’s nice. - Love Rhythm’.

The little girl’s concern was that "it could be damaging to young girls and judging people’s weight is not nice". Rhythm’s mother told Today that her husband and she is extremely proud of the response, adding that the teacher also handled the situation nicely.

“Rhythm’s teacher was so responsive and handled the situation with such care. She told her she understands how she would be upset about this and that she didn’t have to write out the answer," said Naomi.

People need to understand that it is not funny or okay to comment on somebody’s body weight. As Rhythm said that it could be damaging to young girls, because school is the foundation on which the rest of their lives are built. If kids learn these things in school at such a young age, then nobody should expect them to grow up as a smart and non-judgmental individuals.
